title: Powell Says Higher Inflation May Be Around Longer Than Fed Expected; Harker and Daly Back Taper of Fed Asset Purchases
text:
Top News

Powell: Bottlenecks Could Lead to Longer Interval of High Inflation

Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell said that a recent spell of higher inflation might last longer than central bank officials had anticipated, but he repeated his expectation that the price surge should eventually fade.

"The current inflation spike is really a consequence of supply constraints meeting very strong demand. And that is all associated with the reopening of the economy, which is a process that will have a beginning, middle and an end," Mr. Powell said Wednesday during a moderated discussion hosted by the European Central Bank.

Two Fed Officials Signal Support for Starting Bond Buying Taper

Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia President Patrick Harker said he supports slowing the pace of the U.S. central bank's asset purchases soon, and San Francisco Fed leader Mary Daly said it could be appropriate to start tapering them.

Key Developments Around the World

Record $1.416 Trillion Inflow for Fed's Reverse Repo Facility

Month- and quarter-end forces are hitting money markets and driving record inflows into the Federal Reserve's reverse repo facility. On Wednesday, the facility took in $1.416 trillion from money-market funds and other eligible firms, compared with negibile levels of activity in spring. Many firms like to buttress holdings however they can at month end, and for some parking cash with the Fed is a good way to do that, so it is likely inflows could be even larger on Thursday, the last day of September and the third quarter.

—Michael S. Derby

House Republicans Confront Dilemma on Infrastructure Vote

Unlike in the Senate where the infrastructure bill secured the support of 19 Republicans, the bill faces a more complicated path in the House, where a much smaller slice of the caucus is expected to back the measure.

Industry Lobbyists Aim to Pick Apart $3.5 Trillion Spending Bill

Hidden Debt Plagues China's Belt and Road Infrastructure Plan

Hidden debt and problematic projects are emerging as features of China's Belt and Road Initiative, with reports pointing to headwinds facing President Xi Jinping's international infrastructure-development program.

Financial Regulation Roundup

SEC Proposal Seeks Transparency in Money Managers' Voting Power

The proposal follows a yearslong concern among some Securities and Exchange Commission officials that current disclosures make it difficult for individual investors to see how asset managers cast shareholder votes on their behalf.

Foreign Bribery Prosecutor Daniel Kahn Departs Justice Department

Over an 11-year stint at the Justice Department, Daniel Kahn, whose last day was Wednesday, rose from his position as a trial attorney to become its most recognizable expert on the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act.

China Evergrande Selling Bank Stake to State-Owned Firm

A Chinese state-owned enterprise struck a deal to buy most of China Evergrande Group's stake in a commercial bank for $1.5 billion, the latest sign authorities are trying to help the property giant resolve some of its financial troubles.

Research

Financial Oversight Overhauls Don't Always Stem From Crises

Does major reform of financial regulation only happen in the wake of a crisis? Yes and no, according to a new paper by Peter Conti-Brown of the University of Pennsylvania and Michael Ohlrogge of New York University Law School. "Using a suite of legislative importance metrics, we show that the crisis legislation hypothesis fits strongly for securities laws, but far less so for banking legislation," they write. "We conclude, therefore, that reformers would be ill-advised to only push for government interventions in the banking system post-crises, and that those seeking to understand dysfunctions in U.S. bank regulation will need to seek fuller explanations."

—Michael S. Derby

Commentary

Democrats Pursue Europe's Welfare State on American-Style Taxes

The $3.5 trillion fiscal package Democrats hope to pass represents an ambitious expansion of the social safety net, as they seek to emulate welfare states common in Western Europe but without high taxes Europeans pay, Greg Ip writes.

Basis Points

Worker filings for unemployment benefits are expected to have fallen last week as the number of Covid-19 cases declined and hurricane-related disruptions eased.

Walmart, the largest private U.S. employer, said it aims to hire 150,000 workers ahead of the busy holiday shopping season, another sign that retailers are rushing to staff stores and warehouses in a tight U.S. labor market.

Eurozone business and household confidence rose slightly in September, beating forecasts for a small decline, as the European Commission's economic sentiment indicator edged up from a reading of 117.6 in August to 117.8. Economists polled by The Wall Street Journal expected the index to come in at 116.5. (Dow Jones Newswires)

The number of houses under contract in the U.S. rose sharply in August following two months of declines, according to the National Association of Realtors, which said its Pending Home Sales Index increased 8.1% to 119.5 from July. Economists polled by The Wall Street Journal expected the indicator to increase by 1.2% on month. (DJN)

Canada's industrial product price index declined 0.3% in August from the previous month, Statistics Canada said. Producer prices fell by a revised 0.2% in July. On a 12-month basis, the index rose 14.3% in August. (DJN)
